Hypenotic The Jekyll Butler

Visualizing Food

08 Jul 2011

I love to cook. It’s not something that comes to me naturally, or that I have a real aptitude for, but it’s for these reasons that I find cooking to be such a rich, challenging, and engaging sensory experience. There’s nothing more rewarding than being able to eat the fruits of your labour- literally.

Despite lacking natural ability in the kitchen,  I do have an innate understanding of one thing- visual communication. I’m a designer and illustrator by trade, but more importantly I’m a visual learner. If you were to present me with a list of ingredients and instructions, but with absolutely no visual aid, I’d be less likely to understand, process, and therefore produce your delicious recipe. It’s nothing personal- I’m sure your Aunt’s casserole is divine, this is just something hardwired into my biology.

Now, give me information presented in conjunction with pictures, charts, diagrams, and some solid design and I’ll be enthralled. Take the minimalist photography of culinary grad, William Matthew Valle, or the sequential photographs and clear instructions in Jane Horby’s book, What to Cook and How to Cook it, *and IKEA’s Homemade is Best.  They’re all good on the eyes, while still appealing to the stomach.
**
I created this Guacamole recipe for all you other visceral creatures out there.
*
